'''Ralph DeLancey Izard''' (26 February 1785 – 21 January 1822) was a [[United States Navy]] officer who became a hero for his actions at [[Tripoli]], during the [[First Barbary War|Barbary Wars]]. The destroyer [[USS Izard (DD-589)|USS ''Izard'']] (DD-589) was named after him.
==Early service== Ralph DeLancey Izard was born 26 February 1785 at [[Charleston, South Carolina]], the son of a prominent political family. His father was Senator [[Ralph Izard]], who served as a delegate to the [[Continental Congress]] (1782–1783), U.S. Senator from [[South Carolina]] (1789–1795), and was [[President pro tempore of the United States Senate]].
Ralph was appointed [[Midshipman]] 2 October 1799.
[[File:burning of the uss philadelphia.jpg|left|thumb|''Burning of the frigate ''Philadelphia'' in the harbor of Tripoli, February 16, 1804'', by [[Edward Moran]], painted 1897.]]
==The Burning of the ''Philadelphia''== Izard volunteered and took part in the expedition under Lieutenant [[Stephen Decatur]], commanding the [[ketch]] [[USS Intrepid (1798)|''Intrepid'']], which entered the harbor of [[Tripoli]] 16 February 1804 and destroyed the captured U.S. [[frigate]] [[USS Philadelphia (1799)|''Philadelphia'']] in what [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Lord Nelson]] called the most daring act of the age. Izard was assigned duty under Lt. Decatur, with [[Midshipman]] John Rowe and 15 men, to hold the spar deck.
==Later Duty== He also took part in the attacks on Tripoli during August and September 1804 as part of Commodore [[Edward Preble]]'s squadron. He was promoted to [[Lieutenant]] on 27 January 1807. Lt. Izard died 21 January 1822 at [[Charleston, South Carolina]].
==Marriage== In 1808, Izard married Eliza Pinckney, daughter of Maj-Gen [[Charles Cotesworth Pinckney]], signatory to the Constitution, and a granddaughter of Col [[Colonel Charles Pinckney|Charles Pinckney]], chief justice of South Carolina.
==Namesake== The [[destroyer]] [[USS Izard (DD-589)|''Izard'']] was launched and named in Lt. Izard's honor on 8 August 1942. She served in the [[Asiatic-Pacific Theater|Pacific]] during [[World War II]], including the battles of [[Battle of Kwajalein|Kwajalein]], the [[Battle of the Philippine Sea|Philippine Sea]], [[Battle of Leyte|Leyte]], and [[Battle of Iwo Jima|Iwo Jima]], among others. She received 10 [[battle stars]] for service.
